variant.question: During flight, the part of the aircraft concerning the measurement of engine parameters becomes blocked

options.text: The auto-pilot may experience erroneous readings and constantly adjust thrust levels
The ASI will be affected
The angle of attack readings will be affected
The altimeter, VSI and ASI will be affected

variant.question: According to EASA CS 25 - which of the following statements regarding an Emergency Demonstration is correct?

options.text: Not more than 50% of all emergency exits should be available.
The maximum number of seats for passengers below an age of 24 months should be 20 or less.
A full demonstration to passengers about all emergency equipment on board should be done before flight.
Emergency exits should be free from any obstruction.

variant.question: Which of the following reasons is most likely to force a twin-jet aeroplane to perform an emergency landing?

options.text: Multiple bird strikes during the take-off roll that cause an engine failure and erratic operation of the remaining engine.
Total loss of one of the three available hydraulic systems, on an aircraft with flight controls that are hydraulically powered.
An in-flight fire in the forward galley that has been positively identified as extinguished.
A total loss of the automatic pressurisation system just after take-off requiring manual intervention by the crew.

variant.question: Which of the following reasons is most likely to force a twin-jet aeroplane to perform an emergency landing?

options.text: Multiple bird strikes during the take-off roll that cause an engine failure and erratic operation of the remaining engine.
A total loss of the automatic pressurisation system just after take-off requiring manual intervention by the crew.
A total loss of one of three available hydraulic systems, on an aircraft with flight controls that are hydraulicly powered.
An in-flight fire in the forward galley that has been positively identified as extinquished.

variant.question: You encounter an engine failure with your single engine aeroplane overhead a dense forest. Choose the best configuration for an emergency landing.

options.text: 1. Flaps down, gear up and aim for low trees.
1. Flaps up, gear down and aim for high trees.
1. Flaps down, gear down and aim for low trees.
1. Flaps up, gear up and aim for high trees.

variant.question: Following an emergency landing which will need an escape from the aircraft, you will: - remain on the runway. - clear the runway using the first available taxiway. - keep one engine or the APU running in order to maintain the electrical power supply on. - turn off all systems. The combination regrouping all the correct statements is:

A turbojet aeroplane is experiencing a mid-air emergency forcing the aeroplane to make an emergency landing at the nearest suitable aerodrome. The aeroplane remains undamaged after the landing, however the pilot decides that an emergency evacuation of the passengers is required. The emergency evacuation checklist states the following:Parking brake: SET 
 All engines: OFF 
 Evacuation: INITIATEWhich of the following statements is correct?

options.text: This checklist ensures that the outside of the aeroplane is safe before people leave the relative safety of the cabin.
The evacuation command should be first since passengers leaving the aeroplane will tend to follow the normal, safe paths.
The evacuation command should be first followed by the engine shutdown since it takes time until the first passenger exits the cabin.
Setting the parking brake should be last on the checklist since pilots are trained to set the parking brake whenever the aeroplane has stopped.

variant.question: An engine fire warning will switch on the relevant fire shut-off handle. The fire shut-off handle will be switched off when:

options.text: fire is no longer detected.
all the fire extinguishers connected to this engine have been triggered.
the fire extinguisher has been triggered.
the fire shut-off handle has been pulled.

variant.question: In the event of an engine exhaust pipe fire while on the ground, the pilot should abort the start or continue with the shutdown and...

options.text: carry out a dry crank of the engine.
fight the fire with a water fire-extinguisher.
pull the fire shut off handle and trigger the engine fire-extinguishers.
carry out a damp crank of the engine.

variant.question: In the event of an engine exhaust pipe fire while on the ground, the pilot should abort the start or continue with the shutdown and

options.text: carry out a dry crank of the engine.
pull the fire shut off handle and trigger the engine fire-extinguishers.
carry out a damp crank of the engine.
fight the fire with a water fire-extinguisher.

variant.question: In the event of an engine exhaust pipe fire while on the ground, the pilot should abort the start or continue with the shutdown and..

options.text: carry out a dry crank of the engine.
carry out a damp crank of the engine.
fight the fire with a water fire-extinguisher.
pull the fire shut off handle and trigger the engine fire-extinguishers.

variant.question:
An aircraft is forced to perform an emergency landing. The Checklist after landing is as follows:Parking Brake_____Set 
 Engines___________Shutdown 
 Cabin_____________EvacuateWhich of the following statements is correct?

options.text: The checklist is used to ensure the outside of the aircraft is safe before evacuating passengers out of the relatively safe cabin.
The order of the evacuation checklist does not matter, the commander may opt to evacuate the cabin before setting the parking brake.
The evacuation checklist is never mandatory, it shall be completed if time permits only as the most important step is to evacuate the passengers as soon as possible using the slides.
Evacuation should come before the engine shutdown since it takes time for the passengers to evacuate. By the time passengers have evacuated, the engines will have stopped.

variant.question: In case of an engine exhaust pipe (tailpipe) fire while on the ground, you should abort the starting procedure and:

options.text: carry out a dry cranking.
fight the nozzle fire with a water fire extinguisher.
carry out a damp cranking.
pull the fire shut off handle and trigger the engines fire extinguishers.

variant.question: An aircraft experiences an engine failure followed by a Fire on Engine No 2. The aircraft lands and stops on the runway and the fire fighting services start extinguishing the fire. Cabin crew members see smoke coming from engine No 2. Communication with flight crew is not possible. What should they do?

options.text: Evacuate via left doors only.
Wait until permission from the commander.
Evacuate via left and right doors.
Wait until the fire is out.
